questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Vitamin C

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of neurolathyrism. Vitamin C is beneficial in cases of lathyrism.

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings

  • Osteolathyrism (Odoratism): In animals

     

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine’ (BOAA)

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

 

The Ans. is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, which is the location known as the flexion point. The flexion point is critical in vacuum-assisted deliveries because it lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle on the baby's head. This point is chosen because pulling on this location causes flexion of the baby's head, facilitating the proper positioning for delivery. Flexion is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter of the baby's head to present, making the delivery process smoother and safer for both the mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.

 

Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

 

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

 

Functions of pili:

 

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: While important for many cellular functions, the cytoplasmic membrane itself is not typically involved in adhesion.

 

Option B. Mesosomes: These are folded invaginations in the bacterial membrane thought to be artifacts of cell preparation and not involved in adhesion.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS): Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, LPS can play a role in interactions with the host immune system but are not primarily responsible for adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

  • It is soft tissues entrapment.
  • Tendinitis of the rotator cuff is the major cause of a painful shoulder.
  • The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis, and teres minor muscles, and inserts on the humeral tuberosity.
  • The supraspinatus tendon is the most often affected, probably because of its repeated impingement between the humeral head and the undersurface of the anterior third of the acromion and coracoacromial ligament above as well as the reduction in its blood supply that occurs with abduction of the arm. This phenomenon is described as impingement syndrome.
  • The process begins with edema and hemorrhage of the rotator cuff which evolves to fibrotic thickening and eventually to rotator cuff degeneration with tendon tears and bone spurs.
  • Subacromial bursitis also accompanies this syndrome.
  • Symptoms usually appear after injury or overuse, especially with activities involving elevation of the arm with some degree of forward flexion.
  • Impingement syndrome occurs in persons participating in baseball, tennis, swimming, or occupations that require repeated elevation of the arm.
  • Severe pain is experienced when the arm is actively abducted into an overhead position. The arc between 60° and 120° (mid-range abduction) is especially painful. This is also described as “painful arc syndrome”.
  • NSAIDs, local glucocorticoid injection, and physical therapy may relieve symptoms.
  • Surgical decompression of the subacromial space may be necessary in patient refractory to conservative treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initial abduction: Incorrect, as the pain typically does not start at the beginning of abduction but becomes noticeable as the arm reaches mid-range.

 

Option C. Full range of abduction: Incorrect, although the entire range might be uncomfortable, the specific "painful arc" is usually observed in the mid-range.

 

Option D. Overhead abduction: Incorrect, as the term "painful arc syndrome" specifically refers to pain experienced in the mid-range of abduction, not necessarily when the arm is fully overhead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

choices.text: Raised JVP with normal waveform

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent a wave

 

The patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse, which is highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of coordinated atrial contractions, leading to an irregularly irregular ventricular response. This irregularity can be confirmed by a pulse deficit, where the heart rate (as measured by auscultation) is higher than the pulse rate (as felt at the periphery).

 

In atrial fibrillation, the chaotic atrial activity results in the absence of effective atrial contraction. This leads to the absence of a wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP), as a wave is generated by atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent p wave: While it is true that atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of P waves on the ECG, the question specifically asks about the JVP finding, not the ECG finding.

 

Option C. Cannon a wave: Cannon a waves are typically seen in conditions where there is atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block. They are not associated with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform: Raised JVP can occur in various conditions, but the presence of a normal waveform would not be consistent with atrial fibrillation, where the a wave is absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes infection involving the geniculate ganglion? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes zoster infection (varicella-zoster virus) involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It presents as a triad of facial nerve palsy, vesicular eruptions on the pinna and external auditory canal, and vestibulocochlear symptoms. The infection represents a reactivation of the herpes zoster virus that had remained dormant in the geniculate ganglion after previous chickenpox infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome: This is a rare manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, and facial nerve palsy. It is not related to herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion. The facial palsy in this condition is due to granulomatous infiltration of the facial nerve.

 

Option C. Bell's Palsy: While this is also a facial nerve paralysis, Bell's palsy is idiopathic in nature. Although some theories suggest that herpes simplex virus may be involved in some cases of Bell's palsy, it does not specifically involve vesicular eruptions or definitive evidence of geniculate ganglion involvement as seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome: This syndrome (also called Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome) is characterized by recurrent or persistent facial swelling, recurrent facial paralysis, and a fissured tongue (lingua plicata). It is not caused by herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion but is thought to be related to granulomatous disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is specifically characterized by facial nerve palsy due to herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion, presenting with the distinctive triad of facial paralysis, ear/mouth vesicles, and auditory/vestibular symptoms.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities. A provisional diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following cells are affected in multiple sclerosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oligodendrocytes

 

Explanation

 

Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.

 

In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microglia. are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.

 

Option C. Astrocytes. also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.

 

Option D. Ependymal cells. are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In multiple sclerosis, the primary pathological change occurs in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelinating neurons in the CNS. This leads to widespread neurological impairment due to the loss of myelin, affecting the efficiency of nerve signal transmission.

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:

  • Accessibility: The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • Monitoring: This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • Functionality: The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • Ease of Removal: If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.

 

Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.

 

Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

questions.text: A child presented with hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, and bilateral chorioretinitis. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital Toxoplasmosis
Congenital toxoplasmosis is classically associated with the triad of hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis. This triad is often remembered as "C3" where C represents chorioretinitis, calcifications (intracranial), and hydrocephalus (cephalus).

Toxoplasma gondii infection in utero can cause these characteristic findings, and they are critical for the diagnosis. These symptoms result from the parasite's effect on the brain and eyes, leading to fluid accumulation (hydrocephalus), calcified lesions in the brain, and inflammation of the choroid and retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital Syphilis:  The classical triad of congenital syphilis is represented by "INH" - Interstitial Keratitis, Neurosensory Deafness, and Hutchinson's teeth.

 

 

Option C. Congenital Rubella: The triad associated with congenital rubella includes cataracts, heart disease (often patent ductus arteriosus or other cardiac defects), and neurosensory deafness, summarized as "CHD" (Cataract, Heart Disease, Deafness). It does not involve hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, or chorioretinitis.

 

 

Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Neisseria gonorrhea is a bacterial infection that typically does not present with a triad of symptoms and is unrelated to congenital infections leading to hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, or chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:


The classical triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis, which are key findings for diagnosis.

choices.text: Causes the enzyme to work faster only

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an allosteric modifier?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Participates in feedback regulation

 

This statement is generally true. Allosteric modifiers can play a role in feedback regulation, where the products of enzymatic reactions can act as allosteric modifiers to regulate the activity of enzymes in the same metabolic pathway. This helps maintain homeostasis in cellular processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desaturates the enzyme: This statement is not true. Allosteric modifiers do not desaturate enzymes. Instead, they can either activate or inhibit enzyme activity by binding to specific allosteric sites.

 

Option B. Causes the enzyme to work faster only: This statement is not entirely accurate. Allosteric modifiers can have both activating and inhibitory effects on enzyme activity. Some can enhance enzyme activity (activate), while others can decrease it (inhibit).

 

Option C. Binds to the catalytic site: This statement is not true for allosteric modifiers. Allosteric modifiers bind to allosteric sites, which are distinct from the catalytic site. The binding of an allosteric modifier at these sites can lead to conformational changes in the enzyme that affect its activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allosteric Regulation
 

  1. Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  2. Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  3. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme (allosteric activation), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme (allosteric inhibition).
  4. In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier.
  5. The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity. If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity.
  6. In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of variation

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is used to compare the relative variability of different datasets. It is a standardized measure of dispersion of a probability distribution or frequency distribution. The CV is particularly useful because it expresses the standard deviation as a percentage of the mean, making it possible to compare the degree of variation from one dataset to another, regardless of the unit of measurement or magnitude of the mean.

 

  • Co-efficient of Variation [COV] = SD/Mean x 100
  • It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance measures the spread of a set of numbers. It is the average of the squared differences from the mean. While it indicates variability, it does not provide a standardized measure for comparison between different datasets.

 

Option C. Standard Error of Mean (SEM): The SEM measures how much the sample mean of the data is likely to vary from the true population mean. It is used to understand the accuracy of the sample mean but is not used for comparing variability between datasets.

 

Option D. Standard Deviation (SD): Standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. While it indicates the spread of data points, it does not standardize this measure in relation to the mean, which is necessary for comparing different datasets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman came to the OPD with a diagnosis of advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give for her daughter? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advise HPV vaccine

 

The patient's 14-year-old daughter should be advised to take the HPV vaccine.

 

Screening CA cervix begins at the age of 25 years.

 

HPV vaccine

 

  • Contains recombinant VLP (L1 synthetic capsid protein)
  • Types –
    • Cervarix: Bivalent (16,18)
    • Gardasil: Quadrivalent (6,11,16,18)
    • Gardasil 9: Nonavalent (6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58)
    • Dosing as per IAP:
      • Girls 9 to 14 years: 2 doses
      • > 15 years: 3 doses

 

On June 1, 2023 there will be the launch of Indian indigenous vaccine called Cervavac , quadrivalent vaccine produce by Serum Institute of India (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

WHO’s Safe Advisory Group (SAGE) in 2021 advised regarding updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

 

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

 

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screen for BRCA mutation: BRCA mutation causes breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer

 

Option C. Screen for PTEN mutation: PTEN mutation (chromosome 10) causes Cowden syndrome, has 20-30% risk of developing endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Perform cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsy is not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine is essential for preventing cervical cancer and should be administered to girls aged 9 to 14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B deficiency

 

Vitamin B deficiency: This is the correct answer. The symptoms given in question are suggestive of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is caused by a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Chronic alcoholism can lead to thiamine deficiency, which results in neurological symptoms like those described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Vitamin A deficiency typically presents with different symptoms, such as night blindness and skin issues, and is not related to the neurological symptoms seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to various bone related problems like Rickets and Osteomalacia, but it is not associated with the specific symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements seen in this case.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily presents with symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and bleeding gums. It is not related to the neurological symptoms described in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke encephalopathy – An acute, reversible but life-threatening condition. Clinical Vignette include Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Nystagmus, Ataxia.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: Associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.

 

List of Oncogenic Microbe:

choices.text: More common in females
Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.text: All are true about patients with trigeminal neuralgia except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deep seated pain

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, severe, electric shock-like or stabbing pain that is typically superficial and localized to the face. It most often affects the V2 (maxillary) and V3 (mandibular) divisions of the trigeminal nerve. The pain associated with trigeminal neuralgia is not deep-seated but rather feels as if it is on the surface of the face, which makes option C incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in females: This is true. Trigeminal neuralgia is generally more common in females than in males.

 

Option B. Pain along V2 and V3 division of the trigeminal nerve: This is also true. While trigeminal neuralgia can affect any of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve, the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) branches are more commonly affected than the ophthalmic (V1) branch.

 

Option D. No objective signs of sensory loss: This is correct. Trigeminal neuralgia typically does not show any objective signs of sensory loss or neurological deficit on examination, which can make diagnosis challenging.

 

Educational Objective:


Trigeminal neuralgia is marked by sharp, superficial pain that may affect the V2 and V3 divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is important to recognize that the pain is superficial and not deep-seated. This condition more commonly affects females and presents without objective sensory loss.

 

Reference - Harrison/Trigeminal neuralgia

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

choices.text: Low TSH levels
Low free T4 levels
Low serum T3 levels
Radioactive iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Low TSH levels
 

Grave’s disease in an autoimmune disease characterized by production of antibodies against the TSH-Receptor which stimulates the gland resulting in release of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) producing symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. Elevated T3, 4 produce reduction in TSH via negative feedback.

 

Other options:

 

Option B, C: Elevated levels of T3, T4 are seen in Grave’s disease.

 

Option D: Due to stimulation of the gland, there is Homogenous uptake on RAIU scan.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Graves' disease, low TSH levels are a key diagnostic marker reflecting the increased production and release of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland to reduce TSH secretion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Grave’s disease/Chap 384

choices.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

 

The given X-ray shows eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins with soap bubble appearance indicative of Giant cell tumour (GCT). Treatment of GCT includes Curettage or Excision with bone grafting.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells - a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
  • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
  • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.

 

Radiological Features

 

  • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.

 

Treatment

 

  • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
  • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective

 

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Nugent score is for diagnosis of? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis


The Nugent score is a microbiological scoring system used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis (BV). It is based on the examination of a vaginal smear under a microscope to evaluate the presence and quantity of bacterial morphotypes, particularly Lactobacilli, Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus. A high Nugent score indicates a decrease in normal Lactobacilli and an increase in pathogenic bacteria, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This scoring system provides a more objective and standardized diagnosis compared to clinical criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis:  is incorrect because trichomoniasis is diagnosed through wet mount microscopy, culture, or molecular tests, which detect Trichomonas vaginalis, not by the Nugent score.

 

Option C. Candidiasis : is incorrect as it refers to yeast infections typically diagnosed by identifying Candida species on wet mount, KOH preparation, or fungal cultures, not using the Nugent score.

 

Option D. Chlamydia: is incorrect since Chlamydia is diagnosed through nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), culture, or antigen detection, not by the Nugent scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nugent score is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. It is a microbiological scoring system where the vaginal smear is analyzed for the number of lactobacilli and abnormal bacteria. The clinical scoring system for bacterial vaginosis is the Amsel's criteria, which includes the whiff test, clue cells, alkaline pH, and whitish discharge.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

 

The symptoms of patient clearly indicate vitamin A deficiency. One of the other clinical feature of vitamin A deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis aka Phrynoderma which is characterized by excessive keratinization of certain area of body such as elbows and knees. Vitamin A prevents hyperkeratinization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratosis pilaris rubra: Keratosis pilaris rubra is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of small, red bumps on the skin, often on the arms and thighs. It primarily affects the skin and does not directly relate to the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Eczema: Eczema is a chronic skin condition characterized by red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches. While eczema can affect the skin, it is not associated with night blindness, corneal drying, or Bitot's spots.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis: Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders that lead to dry, scaly, and thickened skin. It primarily affects the skin's texture and is not commonly associated with night blindness and corneal drying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.

 

Ref-Dinesh Puri 3rd e/pg. 393,

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Becker's naevus

 

The given image shows Becker's naevus.

 

  • The condition in question is an epidermal melanocytic nevus, characterized by the clustering of melanocytes in the epidermis.
  • It is commonly hairy and tends to appear during adolescence when there is heightened sensitivity to androgens, especially in areas like the outer arms, scapular region, and chest.

 

A triad of features can be seen:

 

  1. Hypertrichosis
  2. Acne
  3. Brownish Hyperpigmentation

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Becker's naevus is a patchy, hyperpigmented lesion that often develops during adolescence and may include hypertrichosis, distinguishing it from congenital conditions such as Mongolian spots, Naevus of Ito, and congenital melanocytic naevi.

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 112, page no 2232

Question Level – EASY
